>HOW TO ASK FOR ADVICE:
Reminder that context is important. If you're asking for advice don't just ask 'This girl ghosted me, why?', we can't understand what your situation is like. Try to help other anons understand so they can help you, add as much (useful) context as possible:
●Age
●Experience with women/social skills

There is a variety of ways people experience what they call "anxiety," so it's hard to be specific without a fucking doctor's appointment or therapy. However, there are likely techniques to alleviate the physiological symptoms you experience. Some that help me are
>diaphragmatic breathing
>pelvic floor relaxing
>softening the gaze
>soft palette relaxing
>adjusting posture upright
These are techniques for a sympathetic nervous system response, aka "fight flight freeze." Maybe they'll work for you, maybe they won't, because
>There is a variety of ways people experience what they call "anxiety."
What you call anxiety could instead be mind racing, accelerated heartbeat, sweating, blood rushing to head, or something else entirely. Look up your symptoms, learn techniques, practice them a few days, then go out ands use them when you feel anxious.

Then, one of the best pieces of advice from the old PUAs is the three second rule. See a girl you like, count to three and go in. The longer you wait, the more you psyche yourself out, AND the less confident you seem to her. Plus, stalk around too long and you'll genuinely creep her out

here's what I've always done as Step 0:

5--> get to know her as a person and see if there's compatibility.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28107601
I went to college right out of high school and that's what happened to me. I dropped out and went to work.

I'm now back in college now 13 years later and I'm getting basically straight A's. What changed is I now know what it is I want to be doing with some certainty, rather than doing it because I feel like I have to or that I'm expected to. I have a degree and a job in mind and I actively want those things. Having that end goal in mind radically changed college from a slog I had to do into something now that I (mostly) enjoy, although that doesn't mean it's not stressful.

If you struggle with procrastination and distraction. Set up a specific schedule. There are lots of excel schedule templates and allocate your time specifically, what days at what times and for how long you are going to work on coursework. Also be sure to get out of the house and take breaks. Light exercise can also help calm the mind, short meditations can also be good. Also having a designated space is helpful, but if you're like me and don't have a big enough apartment to do that, going to the college or just even a nearby library can help.

Also a big part of my success was cutting back from a 'full time' course load to 2 classes a term, it's massively helpful in both stress and workload. I go slower and (arguably) spend more money, but I've passed nearly every class with an A, so I see it as being a worthwhile tradeoff.

Try some of that stuff, but also make sure you can answer the 'why' question. If you can't than maybe it's time to figure that out. Spend 20 minutes a day googling stuff. If you're interested in Computer Science. Investigate specialized fields of CS and figure out niches that sound interesting and then go look to see if/what jobs of that kind are available in your area to see if it's actually a job that exists in meaningful quantities in the area you live or an area you are willing/want to move to, and do this for one aspect of CS every day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28107936
*every day until you have a list of 3 or 4 specific jobs that sound interesting to you.

That way if you get further along in the process and it stops being appealing for whatever reason you still have a good handful you can peruse with the degree you're working on. If you can't find at least 3, investigate other degrees and if you still can't find 3, maybe it's time to reconsider being in college, maybe working full time just makes more sense right now, like I had to do.

My dude, finding a woman can be hard, finding a woman who is good for you can be even harder.

Much like everything it becomes easier the more you do it and the more you know what you want to achieve.

And I could rant on about all the intricacies but the most important thing especially at the start is to have a way to naturally meet new people (not just women specifically) and for those people to have the opportunity to get to know you and for you to have the opportunity to know them.

My personal recommendation is to try out dancing. Salsa, swing, ballroom, anything that has to do with a partner. Go for a few weeks and once you start getting acquainted with the people in your class, start going with them to relevant parties in your area. That way you achieve both getting to know the people in your class better and get to meet new people in the party.

Of course this works better in big cities.

And I know this can be overwhelming if you are not that extroverted but that is the point to slowly build up the sociality muscle, because it is very much like a muscle.

-An introvert that after working out his social muscle most people believe is an extrovert

posts.sub: How do I stop being a perfectionist?
posts.com:
I want to be a filmmaker or something along those lines but I am crippled by my perfectionism, particularly when it comes to writing. I feel like everything I make has to be perfect, the greatest thing ever made, because otherwise what’s the point? Does the world need another movie that’s just “okay” but nothing more?

The result of this is that I end up not writing much at all because it’s just too hard to stay motivated, but I feel like this is sabotaging myself.

How can I either improve my work to extraordinary quality or just stop caring about that and be okay with what I’be been able to do so far?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
People have to practice for a long time (usually) at any one particular artistic pursuit before they fall into their own unique style. After long enough their true expressions and style start to shine through and it becomes easier and easier to transmit that to paper or film or whatever. But you need to get very familiar with practice exercises. Think of it like weight lifting or shooting 3 pointers. after a while it will be automatic and then when that happens you can relax and really imbue the art with your personal touch

Most people suck dick for a long time before becoming competent and then breaking through into their own style

Okay since I see a lot of poor, clueless fucks like you, I'm gonna give a couple of quick tips on how to text with women:

1. NEVER say hello. It dulls the conversations right off the bat and makes you sound like all the other boring assholes that bombard her with attention. Start with a pick up line, a statement, literally anything else is better than texting her "hi!". If you follow this simple rule you stand out immediately.

2. NEVER say goodbye either. Ending the conversation formally implies that you didn't do anything else while you were texting her, you basically gave her 100% of your attention. That's a huge turnoff for any female. Also, if you say goodbye, it will feel like a new conversation every time you text her again and texting you will feel more and more tedious to her because of it. Simply don't reply and pick up the convo later like nothing happened. It will create a constantly flowing, casual vibe between you and that is what girls are looking for. That's what they want you to make them feel.

3. NEVER ask questions. Or at the very least, try to ask direct questions as rarely as possible. You're a man, men don't ask questions, men make statements. If you want to know something about her, phrase it as a statement or a command. Instead of saying "How was your day?" text her "I hope your day went well" or "Tell me about your day!". And if you can't avoid asking a question, for the love of God, don't use a question mark. Either leave it off completely, or use a thinking emoji instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28110044
4. Use emojis. Yes, there is a stigma against men using emojis, but it's bullshit. The key is to be creative with them. Don't spam the same couple of ones all the time, mix it up. It creates a visually stimulating conversation instead of a plain wall of text. Another trick is to send them in a separate message, because there are a lot of dating and messaging apps that only give her a preview of the last message you sent her. So for example, you text her something, then send an emoji separately, she will see that she has more than one message, but she will only see the emoji in the preview. This will make her intrigued and curious about you as a whole and she will actually read what you send her instead of just leaving it on "seen".

5. Make your intentions clear from the get go. Don't beat around the bush, make it known that you are interested in her in a romantic way, but don't be too blunt about it. You gotta make it fun and playful, this is what pick up lines are for. You can use some existing ones or come up with your own, the key is to experiment a lot. You also gotta move fast with this, either start the convo with a pick up line, or use one during the first couple of exchanges.

6. Double texting should be limited. If she doesn't respond for a longer period of time, you may try to chat her up again, but is she keeps doing it you gotta let her go. There are instances where she genuinely wanted to text you back but couldn't for a legitimate reason, so don't assume the worst immediately, but it's usually a good indicator that she's losing interest. If you do double text her, make sure to not seem overly butthurt, but also convey that you won't tolerate being ignored for too long. Make it snappy, ironic and low effort.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28110112
7. Texting should be a means to an end. It should serve your ultimate end goal of scoring with women. As somebody already said it in this thread, it should mainly be used as a tool to set up real life dates. However, there are many more practical uses for texting, for example keeping a conversation from cooling down when you can't set up a meeting right away. Another important usage is to simply practice talking to women. It doesn't quite substitute face to face practice, but it can still help you hone your conversational skills. With time it will absolutely translate, if you get good at talking to women online, you will be much more comfortable and confident irl.

8. Don't go into lengthy discussions. Keep it light and keep it simple, no need to send paragraphs and talking about serious topics. Girls just want to have fun, never forget it. Joke around, tease her and try to set up the real life date ASAP. You gotta move fast, there are literally dozens of other guys chatting her up all the time, there is no time to fuck around if you want to bag her. If she responds to your pick up line in a positive way, just throw in something like "We should grab a drink" right away. If she says yes you basically done the deed, all you gotta do is show up and show her a good time.

9. Response time should be longer than hers. If you're stuck in a lengthier conversation, you gotta make her feel like she's not the only female you text. Since you didn't close the deal quickly, she gotta assume that it's because you have other options and not because you're a loser. Don't spend hours texting back and forth, go do some other shit and then write her again later. If you failed at the sprint you gotta make it a marathon, otherwise it becomes a slog and she will get bored.

To some extent this stuff it's true. But like with all 4chan advice it trends towards an absolutist mindset. Trying to mentally go through a rules checklist before sending a text with the belief that a single text will make or break your chances will cause you to lose far more opportunities than it will save.

By the time you have a girls number and you're texting her, she has already decided whether or not she is going to fuck you and odds are if you've gone more than a week of texting without her making it obvious that she's down than you should move on.

Yes you need to be socially competent, no following rules you read on the internet will not change that. You just have to fail and learn and it will eventually become second nature, you shouldn't be consciously rainman-ing your text through 800 parallel timelines to check for mistakes. When you are socially competent you won't have to think about it at all. Life is not a video game. Rarely is failure determined by a single input.

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

You do not achieve your goals due to a repeating pattern of mistakes and oversights. If you want to become happy and successful, you need to keep three things in mind:
>1) Repetition is key
This is the absolute biggest issue preventing you from success: you don't understand the value of repetition. Anything that anyone ever became good at, they did by doing it over and over and over. It doesn't matter if it's driving a car, playing an instrument, or even learning how to talk to women -- you cannot become good at something without doing it. Accept the fact that success is inherently linked with failure, and you can only achieve success after failing many, many times.
>2) You are a victim
It's your parents' fault. It's your friends' fault. It's the fault of that kid who bullied you in highschool. It's the fault of your manager. It's the fault of the girl that broke your heart. It's even your dog's fault. It's everyone's fault except yours. This is what you've made yourself believe, and it's holding you back. Even if the whole world is out to get you, it doesn't matter: the world doesn't care about "fair" and it doesn't care who caused your suffering. If you want to get out of your rut, you need to accept the fact that you, and only you, are responsible for the rest of your life. Use negative experiences as motivation for change and never use your troubles as justification for failure.
>3) You are afraid
You're afraid of everything. You are too worried about situational outcomes that may or may not even occur. You go out of your way to minimize humiliation, awkwardness and unpleasantness because you care too much about what people think. You must overcome your ego and fear of embarassment. Do the things you're most afraid of doing. Challenge yourself to do what you think cannot be done.

I hate that I was born with a silver spoon in my mouth. Although my childhood was more comparable to the lower class, after my fathers firm grew exponentially, I started living the moneyless illusion. I started viewing money just as some pine cones you find at the playground to trade with your friends for a shiny rock in kindergarten. Especially during my teenage years, when father sold the firm and moved to a tax haven [still losing more money daily (due to inflation) than most make in a year] where my standards grew even higher.
I was never really spoiled though. If I wanted something, I had to earn it. Either by working part time at his firm or with school performance. Christmas and birthdays were the only days I got things that are generally considered expensive.
With all that said, I still got accustomed to living on the high foot. Riding in expensive cars, resort vacations, restaurants, flying expensive airlines, sometimes multiple times a week, and generally living a carefree life. But now, that I’m in college and have to work for my shit (essentially kicked out after hs) I realize I will literally never be able to restore this kind of life. Unlike my father who was lucky and smart enough to create and maintain his wealth, I’ll most likely be stuck in a 9-5 in the middle class. And to most that may not sound so bad, but my world view and standards were so warped by “living the life”, that anything less is depressing. Like a asian kid who never lived up to his parent’s ideals, but in this case I’m both the kid and the parents. The only thing I have to look forward to is inheritance, which will be split between two separate families and multiple heirs anyways…

posts.com:
Anyone know of any friendly communities for a new developer like myself to get involved with? I'm looking for sites where I can collaborate with other devs on my projects, or even start networking with people.

I haven't been to college, I've just completed several courses on these languages, and I'm sort of at a loss of where to begin. I was hoping to find a community of people to find my footing.

I can work with JavaScript, Python, C++, and C#. However I am not fluent at any of these. At the very least, if I don't know how to do something, I have enough understanding of these languages to figure it out. Now that I've completed these courses, I'm hoping to find some projects to work on, and some people to work with.

I'm hoping to be able to do some freelance work on the side once I gain some confidence in what I can deliver.

Any suggestions?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The easiest way I would say is to try to contribute to a medium/small size open source project. Usually those kinds of projects have smaller tickets and communicative devs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28110278
Thanks! I'll definitely start looking around for something like this. Would you happen to have any leads on such a project that I might be able to look into?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In terms of open source projects, you could probably find projects for literally anything you are interested in. Some examples of very big open source projects: the Linux kernel, the PostgreSQL database engine, the Tor web browser (and tools), the Python interpreter, etc. The ones I listed require a significant amount of background knowledge in specific topics like OS, databases, distributed systems, and programming languages, but you can find smaller scale projects (a lot of software you use on a daily basis is probably open source, without you realizing it) that have a lower barrier to entry (or you can pirate a textbook and go fucking ham in any of those areas of CS desu - just requires motivation and time).

Another thing you could get involved in if you like video games is modding - it's not too difficult to make a basic mod for a game with a well-established modding community, and you have total control over the scope of the mods you make - i.e. you don't need to put in 2000 hours building some crazy multiplayer mode mod! Something as simple as an extra GUI widget works too. A benefit of modding would be that you will have legit users of your mod who will report bugs and request features, etc. and since you are the sole maintainer of the mod, it's kind of like a game in itself to work on those. I think that's pretty fun :)

>Should I go forward with my life and have a hard time finding a husband or sacrifice my hobbies, interests and ranch searching for a husband in the city?
Follow your dream. Especially for a sperg, you will be miserable if you end up in some shitty townhouse playing house with a guy you settled for. The easier thing is generally finding a guy who already wants--and preferably has--the kind of life you want, and you can move in with him (after getting married, of course). posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28102905
>I'll also be miserable if I stay a single childless virgin
Those are all redundant. Changing any one of them without changing the others isn't going to make you happy in the long run, either.

This aside, you have a question of priorities: you want a husband and family, and you want to live in the countryside. If you don't want to sacrifice one or the other, then it makes sense to do what gives you the best chance of finding both. Finding a worthwhile life partner is hard, but the process doesn't depend on location. Living in the countryside, though, is something that you can obviously never do in the city.
This is why I suggest *preparing* for moving to your own dream place by attending classes, events, and so on. You will be giving yourself chances to meet someone special while also making definite progress towards at least one of your goals. If you just drop your plans and try to find any guy in the city, you might increase your dating pool (although the quality of most of the guys is questionable), but this chance comes with a higher risk that you'll never get to your preferred setting.

>Is he going to sell his house to find another one with me?
Homeownership rates aren't very high if you're in your 20s, so odds are he'd be more likely to move to a place you choose together once he marries you.

Also, this goes without saying, but don't get desperate for a partner. That opens you up to being taken advantage of.

>There is never a guarantee you're going to be able to buy your house at the right time
I don't think you quite understand just how terrible the market is for buyers right now.
This isn't just "not the right time," it's literally the WORST time (outside of unforeseeable war/natural disaster) to buy a house.
You will be paying about $600 a month in inflated interest alone. Not "in interest," but in extra interest that's over a reasonable amount.
Granted, refinancing (when better rates are reinstituted) is typically an option but you're essentially building no equity until after that point.
On top of interest rates, home prices are well above what they should be, like, at least 20-30% above just because people/companies think they can get that much more.
All of this sounds like I'm treating a home as an investment vehicle, but I'm not trying to do that. So, let me put it another way: You're going to pay at least $2,000/mo for a property/mortgage that was "worth" $1,100 a little over a year ago.
On top of that is the utilities/maintenance cost increase for a multi-person dwelling. Hell of a lot more expensive to heat/AC, paint, clean, etc. that's hundreds of times bigger (including outdoor property) than what you're used to.
Property taxes is also a thing, but not as big an issue if you have a half-decent mortgage broker.

I'm not saying planning for the future you want is a bad thing, it's actually very good, but you want to make sure you're not putting the cart before the horse in a hasty rush to get to the market.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28107412
>Could you explain this to me?
A typical refinance is more-or-less clearing the existing mortgage and restarting the debt owed in a new mortgage. It's beneficial for the home owner when interest rates drop because they'll be paying a lower monthly payment. The problem is that the timeframe of the loan is usually restarted. So, if you're 5 years into a 30yr loan (25 years left on loan payments) and refinance you are now zero years into a 30yr loan. A LOT of mortgages tack the 30yrs of interest onto the front end of the loan (a $300k loan at 7% isn't 300k, it's more like 320k...), so the payee isn't putting much, if anything, down against the principal of the loan.
You borrowed 300k, paid 20k over a year, and want to refinance? Your new mortgage isn't going to be for 280k, it's going to be a hell of a lot closer to 295k.
You haven't put 20k (equity) into your home, you've only put 5k. Yes, it sucks, and no amount of bitching will make it not work like that.
It's a tricky situation to navigate. Really only good if you absolutely need to lower the monthly payment or bundle higher interest rate debt into a mortgage at a lower rate.

thought it was 600 a month...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28110736
Ideally you should be getting somewhere around 8 hours of sleep but having the time you go to sleep and wake up be the same every day is almost as important. Having a major shift in your sleep schedule is not good for your health but how bad it is depends on various factors in your life. It is probably not the reason your heart rate is spiking so high, unless your getting less than 5 hours of sleep then shifting to something much different there shouldn't be as prominent of a health effect. Most likely your health problems are due to something else, smoking, drinking, diet, stress, etc. If you look over everything and are doing eveything right abstaining from all detriments to your health and exercising/etc, then its possible your sleep shift is the problem. However the chance of that at your age is minimal. If you want this to change just spend a couple weeks going to sleep and waking up a the same time on both weekends and weekdays(set an alarm) and see if that makes a difference. If changing your sleep schedule to be consistent dosn't work then you should go to a doctor because you might have a real health problem, with your cardiovascular system or lungs.

I'm 18-years-old, turning 19 this year.
For the past year and a half since 2021, dropping out of college due to it turning full Globohomo, I have effectively been a NEET up to now.

I have been diagnosed with a mental condition since a very early age, though I'm not in the mood to disclose it. I still live with my mother, and due to my father having passed away in 2007 and an older brother that has, and always was socially distant towards me, I have never had an authority figure in my life. Since early childhood I have been overweight, and although in recent years I had made many repeated attempts to go on a diet, go on daily bike rides, walks, etc, my health situation has not improved at all.

Speaking of repeated attempts, I had realized some years ago by the time I was 15 that I needed to really get a hold of my life situation and work on fixing my issues, though unfortunately, nothing has been achieved and, more problems have emerged. I have already seen a psychologist once, but it amounted to nothing, and given the absurd expenses and wait times in where I live, seeing a trained professional does not seem to be a practical option.

The mental condition I have that I mentioned before, has harmed my personal life and development, self-discipline and control, motivation/drive, decision making skills, and most prevalently, my social skills. Furthermore, my overweight stature, with the addition of acne wrecking my face, and reflecting on my life situation, has not helped my self-esteem. I have felt cornered and hopeless, and have contemplated suicide on multiple occasions.

My family has been unreceptive, complacent, and unhelpful in any way. Any time I try to talk to them about my issues, they simply tell me to go fix it myself, or offer very vague "advice" at best. Other times, they simply outright blame me for my own issues, and openly refuse to help me.

[ Continued \/ ]

the cost of a year of room and board and tuition at Vassar in 1931 was notably high: a whopping $1,200—or $500 for locals who lived at home. ($1,200 in 1931 is about $19,000 in today’s dollars.)

In 1934, a freshman matriculating at Dartmouth would spend $1,050 on tuition, room and board, and “incidentals.” The expected real cost of a year at Dartmouth, after fraternity fees and other expected expenses were accounted, was $1,700—by TIME’s reporting, “highest in the land.” (That’s about $30,500 in today’s dollars.) That year the U.S. Office of Education surveyed the nation’s colleges about the cost of attendance and found that the average cost for one academic year was $630 ($11,300 today).
These days, the average cost for a year at a four-year college ranges from $9,410 for in-state public tuition to $32,410 for private. Neither of those figures include room and board. But, in general and at many specific places, costs are far higher: just looking at a few of the colleges surveyed by TIME over the years, Vassar these days costs $52,320 for a year’s tuition, and Bates is $64,500 for tuition, room and board and fees.

Ask your parents to help you. Say

>> Ok, I want to get a job. Can you help me on how to make a CV and how to apply for a job.

There's a bunch of videos on YouTube on how to write CVs and cover letters so you can also look there. Job boards also have information on these things.

Use the job boards most relevant to your country, linked in and the websites of the companies you'd like to work for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28109993
Some employers will reject you for the lack of experience at your age, but eventually one will be fine with it. The key is being stubborn as fuck and nagging the shit out of an employer if you want the job. For example my job the I have now pays real well. I knew I was overqualified when I applied, yet I never heard back from the company after a week. Rather than quit I called corporate headquarters, led a message, and emailed them about my application. “Magically” I had my now boss calling me to set up an interview the next morning. Your application will likely get lost or never read and buried under all the others. You just need to stand out by being persistent and not quitting. It’s all a numbers game. I’ve never had a problem finding work by doing this and at most have only applied to 4 companies at a time while between jobs. In regards to your lack of qualifications/experience definitely don’t lie, but exaggerate every positive thing while downplaying anything that’s negative. Any little skill that you have which can translate to the job you need to list and make it sound real nice. And for the love of god don’t be picky. You are not in the position to be picky if you’re a total NEET at the bottom of the barrel. Bite the bullet and take a lower than preferred wage (doesn’t necessarily have to be minimum wage, but don’t price yourself out of the market) and be available for ANY shift. Most people are lazy fucks and refuse to work certain hours or shifts even if it means they’ll be broke. If you’re the guy that will show the fuck up no matter when and get the job done most employers will like you immediately. Being picky about wages and hours is a luxury you get when you get to a better place in life. That’s on if the many things chronically broke people don’t get.

Incel is the upgraded attack from calling a guy "virgin", which fell out of favor because using incel instead is a bonus attack on the person's interests, mental health and moral character. The group has a bad reputation for being terminally online, radicalized, and blasting people in nightclubs, supermarkets or college campus, so by lumping them in with those people, the insult is strengthened.

Autist, by comparison, generally excludes the attack on moral character and shifts the focus to the person being mentally handicapped and therefore stupid (or hyper-focused on shit that doesn't matter) - and on social ineptitude and the person's inability to read the room. There isn't really a 'warning' element of "they are a personal threat to you and should be avoided" in calling someone an autist like there is with incel.
